title: 108_hr669
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protect Children from Video Game Sex and Violence Act of 2003". The video game industry has grown to a $10 billion market. Video games with sexual or violent content can harm minors, according to public health groups. Viewing entertainment violence can lead to aggressive attitudes in children. The entertainment industry rates video and computer games for adult suitability based on graphic content. A study found that 78% of minors aged 13 to 16 were able to purchase "Mature" rated games. The sale of these games impacts interstate commerce nationwide. There is a national interest in preventing minors from buying adult-themed games. Legislation is needed to restrict the sale of adult-themed video games containing graphic content without limiting adults' access to these games. Prohibition on sale or rental of adult video games to minors added to United States Code, restricting access for minors. Definitions related to video game content and minors are outlined in this chapter. It includes terms like 'graphic violence' and 'content harmful to minors', with specific criteria for what constitutes harmful content. The term 'minor' is defined as a person aged 17 and younger. The term 'minor' is defined as a person aged 17 and younger. 'Nudity' is the visual depiction of male or female genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or female breast with less than fully opaque covering. 'Sexual conduct' includes acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, or physical contact with genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or female breast. 'Strong sexual content' refers to the visual depiction of human nudity or explicit sexual behavior. The text chunk discusses the prohibition on selling or renting adult video games to minors, with penalties for violations. It defines terms like sexual behavior, sexual violence, and video games. Violators face fines up to $1,000 for a first offense and more for subsequent violations. The text outlines escalating fines for repeat violations of selling or renting adult video games to minors, with penalties ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 for subsequent offenses.
